Topic: Draw animals in their habitats with labels (e.g., fish in water).
CAN: The student can draw and label a few animals correctly in their general habitats (e.g., a fish in or near what resembles water).
The student can begin to identify simple connections between some animals and the resources they need (e.g., a fish needing water, but might not show how the fish uses water).
CANNOT: The student is likely unable to show the complete and accurate relationship between all living things and their environment as an interconnected system (student likely sees elements in isolation).
The student may struggle to accurately label and represent the resources that animals and plants need to survive (e.g., forgetting to label sunlight for plants or air for humans).
The student may mix up habitats or the animals that belong in them (e.g., placing a deer in the ocean or a fish in a tree).
The student might not show the interaction between different living things and their shared resources (e.g., how multiple animals might depend on the same resource like water).
